facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 499 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 499 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 18, 1964 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revision No. 750 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 18, 1964 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revision No. 750 of 1962.

facts.text: High Court of Punjab delivered judgment and order on March 18, 1964 confirming dismissal of eviction petition.

anchor.surface_text: This is a landlords appeal against an order of the High Court of Punjab, March 18, 1964, confirming the dismissal of his petition for the eviction of the respondent from certain premises taken on rent.

facts.text: Appellant made application under S. 13 of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 for eviction of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had made the application under S. 13 of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 on the allegation that rent for the premises from October 1, 1959 to June 30, 1961 had number been paid.

facts.text: Rent for premises from October 1, 1959 to June 30, 1961 had not been paid, as alleged by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that rent for the premises from October 1, 1959 to June 30, 1961 had number been paid.

facts.text: Rent of the premises was Rs. 32/8/- and water connection charges were Rs. 2/8/-

anchor.surface_text: The rent of the premises was Rs. 32/8/- and the water companynection charges were Rs. 2/8/ -. On the first date of hearing the tenant appeared and tendered Rs. 292/8/- as rent from October 1, 1960 to June 30, 1961.

facts.text: On first date of hearing, tenant tendered Rs. 292/8/- as rent from October 1, 1960 to June 30, 1961, Rs. 7/- as interest and Rs. 25/- as costs.

anchor.surface_text: On the first date of hearing the tenant appeared and tendered Rs. 292/8/- as rent from October 1, 1960 to June 30, 1961. He also paid Rs. 7/- as interest and Rs. 25/- as companyts.

facts.text: Landlord accepted the tendered amounts without prejudice to his claim for earlier period rent.

anchor.surface_text: These amounts were accepted by the landlord without prejudice to his claim that the rent for the earlier period had number been paid.

facts.text: Tenant made two deposits in Court of Senior Sub-Judge, Ludhiana under s. 31 of East Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act, 1934: Rs. 210/- on December 23, 1959 and Rs. 210/- on July 18, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the tenant had made two deposits in the Court of the Senior Sub-Judge, Ludhiana under s. 31 of the East Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act, 1934 on December 23, 1959 and July 18, 1960, the amount being 210/- on each occasion.

facts.text: Tenant claimed deposits under s.31 were valid tender of rent to landlord.

anchor.surface_text: The tenant claimed that this was a valid tender of rent to the landlord.

facts.text: Rent Controller decided tenant was not in default.

anchor.surface_text: The Rent Controller, by his order, decided that the tenant was number in default and the Appellate Authority and the High Court also took the same view.

facts.text: Appellate Authority held deposit under s.31 Relief Act was valid tender under s.13 Urban Rent Restriction Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was held by the Appellate Authority, as well as by the High Court, that the deposit under s. 31 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act was a valid tender under s. 13 of the Urban Rent Restriction Act.

facts.text: High Court followed earlier decision Mam Chand v. Chhotu Ram reported in 1964 1 Pb. 626.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench in the High Court followed an earlier decision of the same Court reported in Mam Chand v. Chhotu Ram 1 .

facts.text: Before hearing commenced, respondent objected to grant of special leave alleging inaccurate untrue and misleading statements in SLP regarding material facts.

anchor.surface_text: Before the hearing companymenced the respondent took Objection to the grant of the special leave stating that the appellant was guilty of making certain inaccurate untrue and misleading statements in respect of certain material facts.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected respondent's contention raised by C.M.P. No. 64 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly -rejected the companytention, raised by C.M.P. No. 64 of 1969.

facts.text: Deposits were made not only of arrears of rent but prospectively for some future period for which rent was not due.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the deposit before the Senior SubJudge was made number only of arrears of rent but prospectively for some future period for which the rent was then number due.

facts.text: Supreme Court held deposit under s.31 Relief of Indebtedness Act not a valid tender under s.13 Urban Rent Restriction Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, therefore, we are of opinion that the deposit under s. 31 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act did number save the tenant from the companysequences of the default as companytemplated by s. 13 of the Urban Rent Restriction Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal and, setting aside the judgment of the High Court, order the eviction of the tenant from the premises rented out by him.

facts.text: Supreme Court ordered eviction of tenant with three months time to vacate premises.

anchor.surface_text: order the eviction of the tenant from the premises rented out by him. He shall have three months time in which to vacate the premises.

facts.text: Costs throughout to be borne by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The companyts throughout must also be borne by the respondent.

facts.text: Tenant deposited Rs. 210/- on December 23, 1959 in Senior Sub-Judge Court Ludhiana.

facts.text: Tenant deposited Rs. 210/- on July 18, 1960 in Senior Sub-Judge Court Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: s. 13 of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act reads as follows Eviction of tenants. A tenant in possession of a building or rented land shall number be evicted therefrom in execution of a decree passed before or after the companymencement of this Act or otherwise and whether before or after the termination of the tenancy, except in accordance with the provisions of this section, or in pursuance of an order made under-section 13 of the Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1947, as subsequently amen

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 31 East Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act 1934
concepts.unlisted_description: Deposit in court by debtor to stop interest

anchor.surface_text: Section 31 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act reads as follows - Deposit in companyrt. Any person who owes money may at any time deposit in companyrt a sum of money in full or part payment to his creditor. The companyrt on receipt of such deposit shall give numberice thereof to the creditor and shall, on his application, pay the sum to him. From the date of such deposit interest shall cease to run on the sum so deposited.

concepts.interpretation: Intended for interest-bearing debtor-creditor relationships, not landlord-tenant rent payments where no interest is ordinarily payable; does not convert Sub-Judge court into rent collector

The charge was that before the Rent Controller there was no issue that the deposit under s. 31 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act was a valid tender of payment, although this was mentioned as a fact in the petition for special leave.

issues.text: Whether there was only one issue before the courts below, namely, whether the deposit under s. 31 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act was a valid tender under s. 13 of the Urban Rent Restriction Act that saved the tenant from eviction

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the same cannot be said of the appellant. There was only one issue, before the Court and it was whether the deposit under one Act was good for the purposes of the other Act. All that the courts had to consider was whether that deposit saved the tenant from eviction or not. The High Court mentioned that this was the only point before all the courts below

issues.text: Whether the deposit under s. 31 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act made by the tenant (including prospectively for future rent) constitutes a valid payment or tender of rent to the landlord under s. 13 of the Urban Rent Restriction Act

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether such payment is a valid payment or tender to the landlord. Section 31 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act reads as follows - Deposit in court. Any person who owes money may at any time deposit in court a sum of money in full or part payment to his creditor.

arguments.claim: The correctness of the High Court decision and the precedent in Mam Chand v. Chhotu Ram is challenged.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrectness of that decision as well as the decision under appeal are challenged before us.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nding the civil law wherever necessary. Incidentally, it provides for deposit in companyrt with a view to giving a chance to debtors to save interest

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed after analysis; reversed High Court.

arguments.claim: There was only one issue before the lower courts: whether the s.31 deposit saved the tenant from eviction under s.13 URRA; no gross misstatement in SLP.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the same cannot be said of the appellant. There I was only one issue, before the Court and it was whether the deposit under one Act was good for the purposes of the other Act. All that the companyrts had to companysider was whether that deposit saved the tenant from eviction or number.

arguments.claim: s.13 URRA lays down the exclusive procedure for tendering rent to avoid eviction: full arrears plus interest and costs on first hearing before Controller; no other deposit procedure provided.

anchor.surface_text: The Act does number lay down any other procedure under which -money can be deposited with any Government Authority. Such provisions are to be found in other Rent Control Acts but are missing in this Act. Eviction, therefore, takes place on the ground of number-payment or tender of rent due within time fixed by the tenancy and 15 days thereafter.

arguments.claim: s.31 EPRIA is intended for debtor-creditor relationships involving interest (to stop interest accrual), as per scheme of the Act (insolvency, usury, etc.); general words do not cover non-interest rent.

anchor.surface_text: This Act was passed to govern the relation between the debtors and creditors. The scheme of the Act bears upon this relationship because it provides for insolvency procedure, usurious loans, damdupat, redemption of mortgages, deposit in companyrt, and sets up Debt Conciliation Boards, suitably amending the civil law wherever necessary.

arguments.claim: No interest ordinarily payable on rent by tenants, so s.31 (which stops interest) does not apply to landlord-tenant; Senior Sub-Judge court not a rent collector.

anchor.surface_text: The phrase must be read to companyer cases of debtors and creditors between whom there is an agreement for payment of interest because the deposit is intended to stop interest from running. No interest is agreed to be paid by tenants, at any rate, number ordinarily, and, therefore, the, section cannot be said to companyer a case between a landlord and a tenant.

arguments.claim: s.31 allows part payment deposit, which cannot be valid full tender required for rent under s.13.

anchor.surface_text: A second pointer is that the amount may be deposited in part which cannot possibly be a valid tender in case of rent.

arguments.claim: Division Bench erred by not noticing two single Judge decisions taking the view that s.31 deposit not valid for rent; those preferable.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that the decision of the Division Bench runs companynter to two other decisions of single Judges of the same High Court who have taken the same view which we are taking here. The decisions are numbericed by the Division Bench but have number been accepted.

arguments.claim: Deposits included prospective future rent, invalid as s.19 read with s.6 URRA prohibits landlord recovering advance rent beyond one month (punishable by jail).

anchor.surface_text: Further the deposit of money in the present case was number only of the rent due but also of future rent. Under s. 19 read with s. 6 of the Urban Rent Restriction Act a landlord is liable to be sent to jail if he recovers advance rent beyond one month.

arguments.claim: Landlords not required to check Senior Sub-Judge court for deposits; notice provision not intended for rent cases.

anchor.surface_text: It is impossible to think that the landlords would be required to go to the Court of the Senior Sub-Judge with a view to finding out whether their tenants have deposited rent due to them or number. No doubt there is a provision for sending a numberice, but we do number think that that numberice is intended to companyer such cases.

holdings.text: The complaint of false averment or gross misstatement in the special leave petition is not sustainable and the contention raised by C.M.P. No. 64 of 1969 is rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the same cannot be said of the appellant. There was only one issue, before the Court and it was whether the deposit under one Act was good for the purposes of the other Act. All that the courts had to consider was whether that deposit saved the tenant from eviction or not. The High Court mentioned that this was the only point before all the courts below and we do not think that the complaint that there had been any false averment in the petition for special leave was sustainable. We accordingly rejected the contention, raised by C.M.P. No. 64 of 1969.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished precedents of gross deliberate misstatements (Hari Narain, Rajabhai); only one issue before lower courts regarding validity of deposit.

holdings.text: There was only one issue before the courts below: whether the deposit under s.31 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act was a valid tender under s.13 of the Urban Rent Restriction Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the same cannot be said of the appellant. There was only one issue, before the Court and it was whether the deposit under one Act was good for the purposes of the other Act. All that the courts had to consider was whether that deposit saved the tenant from eviction or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court confirmed this was the sole point; used to reject misstatement claim.

holdings.text: The deposit under s.31 of the East Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act, 1934 does not constitute a valid payment or tender of rent under s.13 of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 and does not save the tenant from consequences of default.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, therefore, we are of opinion that the deposit under s. 31 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act did not save the tenant from the consequences of the default as contemplated by s. 13 of the Urban Rent Restriction Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.31 for interest-bearing debtor-creditor debts, not rent (no interest ordinarily); s.13 exclusive procedure for tender on first hearing; partial/prospective deposits invalid; policy against turning Sub-Judge into rent collector; prefers single judge precedents over Division Bench.

holdings.text: s.13 of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949 provides the exclusive procedure for tenant to avoid eviction for non-payment: tender full arrears, interest and costs on first hearing before Controller; no other deposit mechanism.

anchor.surface_text: There is only one saving for the tenant and that is when he tenders the full rent in Court before the Rent Controller together with interest and costs. In the present case, the tenant did tender rent but only for a portion of the period and he relied on his deposit under the Relief of Indebtedness Act as due discharge of his liability for the earlier period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.13; contrasts with other Rent Acts that have deposit provisions; applied to facts where tenant tendered only partial.

holdings.text: The tenant is in default of rent for the period October 1, 1959 to September 30, 1960 and liable to eviction under s.13 of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, therefore, we are of opinion that the deposit under s. 31 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act did not save the tenant from the consequences of the default as contemplated by s. 13 of the Urban Rent Restriction Act. We accordingly allow the appeal and, setting aside the judgment of the High Court, order the eviction of the tenant from the premises rented out by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.13 to facts: earlier rent not paid/tendered validly; partial tender on first hearing insufficient.

edges.explanation: The holding directly rejects the complaint of false averment or gross misstatement in the special leave petition, which is the subject of the issue.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the same cannot be said of the appellant. There was only one issue, before the Court and it was whether the deposit under one Act was good for the purposes of the other Act. All that the courts had to consider was whether that deposit saved the tenant from eviction or not. The High Court mentioned that this was the only point before all the courts below and we do not think that the complaint that there had been any false averment in the petition for special leave was sustainable. We accordingly rejected the contention, raised by C.M.P. No. 64 of 1969.

We accordingly allow the appeal and, setting aside the judgment of the High Court, order the eviction of the tenant from the premises rented out by him. He shall have three months time in which to vacate the premises.
iberately chosen to make false statements and false pleas. In the present case the same cannot be said of the appellant. There I was only one issue, b

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the same cannot be said of the appellant. There was only one issue, before the Court and it was whether the deposit under one Act was good for the purposes of the other Act. All that the courts had to consider was whether that deposit saved the tenant from eviction or not.

We accordingly allow the appeal and, setting aside the judgment of the High Court, order the eviction of the tenant from the premises rented out by him. He shall have three months time in which to vacate the premises.
